content.value: Process management in Linux is the ability to view, monitor, control, and terminate running programs (processes).
content.example: Example: Stopping a frozen application using the kill command.

content.value: A process is a program that is currently running in the system. Every time you open an application or run a command, Linux creates a process for it. Linux can run thousands of processes at the same time while managing system resources efficiently.

A process is a program that is currently running in the system. Every time you open an application or run a command, Linux creates a process for it. Linux can run thousands of processes at the same time while managing system resources efficiently.
A Process ID (PID) is a unique number assigned to every running process in Linux.
content.example: Example: PID 2456 represents a specific running program.

content.value: Process management helps users monitor system performance, identify high resource usage, stop unwanted programs, and troubleshoot system issues. System administrators rely heavily on process management to keep systems stable.
ps (process status) is a command used to display information about running processes.
content.example: Example: Viewing processes owned by the current user.

content.description: Displays running processes in various formats.
